New Records: Yoshinobu Yamamoto became the first Japanese-born pitcher to start a playoff game, marking a historic matchup with Yu Darvish, another Japanese-born starter.
Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto allowed two hits over five innings, inducing grounders to first base three times.
Kiké Hernández hit a solo home run in the second inning, giving the Dodgers a 1-0 lead.
Teoscar Hernández crushed a solo home run in the seventh inning, extending the Dodgers' lead to 2-0.
San Diego's batters went 1-for-14 in the fifth game, with key players like Luis Arraez, Fernando Tatis Jr., and Manny Machado struggling.
The Dodgers avoided elimination by winning a decisive Game 5 at home for the first time since 1981.
The Padres ended the series with a 2-1 lead after a strong regular season but couldn't capitalize in the final game.
The game featured a tense pitching duel, with a sellout crowd of 53,183 attendees, including LeBron James and Hollywood stars.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers and Padres rivalry was heating up, meeting in the NLDS for the third time in five years.
The Dodgers had the best regular-season record (98-64) and successfully avoided a third straight NLDS elimination.
The Padres had promising young players but struggled in the playoffs, with their big hitters performing poorly.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers' players and fans celebrated the team's resilience and ability to avoid elimination.
Padres' manager reflected on a season filled with promise but ended in disappointment.
The Dodgers' advancement to the NLCS was a pivotal moment in their playoff journey.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was the longest streak of consecutive retired batters in postseason history (26).
Yamamoto and Darvish, who had previously collaborated to win the World Baseball Classic, were on opposing sides in this playoff matchup.
The Dodgers led 1-0 on Kiké Hernández's home run with two outs in the second inning, marking his 14th career postseason homer.
Others: The game was a pitching showdown, with both teams' starters performing exceptionally well.
The sellout crowd and presence of notable figures like LeBron James added to the game's atmosphere.
